As far as I understand the problem 1% will die and we have no control over that. Approximately 7% will die if there is no access to intensive respiratory support. The aim should be to both increase the availability of respiratory support aggressively and reduce the number of people at any one time requiring it.
At present we can reduce the spread of the virus. We can identify and isolate the at risk groups. We can ensure that the everyone has good nutrition to support their immune systems. We could stagger commuting times to limit the spread in public transport. We could regularly disinfect public surfaces. Etc...

snippet.textDisplay:
The number of cases in UK on March 15 are basically the same Italy had on March 1. British measures now are less than what Italy had already in place at the end of february(for example all schools were already closed in Lombardia (since 26 feb) and there were limitiations for opening hours for cafes, and cities under lockdown, etc). Italian government understood a little late that had to take stronger measures, british one is going to be even more late, I hope for you not too late.
If anyone thinks NHS(or any other system) can be "well prepared" for a situation like this is a deluded.
UK's NHS, according to data I could find (statista.com), had less ICU respirators per population (6.6 every 100000 people) than the Italian SSN (National Sanitary System ) had before this situation (about 12.5 every 100000 people). In addition to this consider that Lombardia and other affected areas have a "far above average" healthcare system compared to the Italian average, which is still ranking #2 worldwide (worldpopulationreview.com), UK ranking #18. Add that for this emergency ICU beds in Italy had been improved in numbers as possible(about +30% +50%) with equipments temporarely removed from operating theaters (that would be closed anyway since hospitals are basically doing none of their "usual business", for sure no planned surgical operations) and bringing back to service equipment that was going to be replaced. Even the last batch of doctors and nurses that are graduating in this session are going to skip their usual apprenticeship and being put straight into service.
Despite all this, Italy is approaching the limit of SSN capacity right now and, unless the trend shows a drastic change soon, in 4 days cases will likely double.
Needless to say if capacity is saturated and is impossible to provide the required assistence to everyone , the human toll would rise faster.
A lot of people might finally realize that there are things that you can not simply just buy when you need, like experienced medical personnel cannot be created out of thin air in few days just when needed, no matter the money you can pay, similarly also other limited resources are hard to find in this situation, like medical equipment and PPE, especially for those countries with no domestic production. Luckyly Italy has a domestic manufacturer of medical ventilators and the entire production is being diverted to address the domestic need, (Italy would need in a month about twice the worldwide year production of medical ventilators)

snippet.textDisplay: I agree with John Edmunds on much of what he says, but I don't agree with his arguments for herd immunity. His justification for allowing large numbers of people to die for this aim, is that it's the only option "unless you get rid of every case in the world". There's definitely, more than one way to respond here and much safer ways than the British govt is opting for. As demonstrated by the drive-thru Covid-19 testing in South Korea and the mobile phone tracking in Taiwan and the properly funded hospital response in Germany (Just 3 examples of many). Talking in curves dehumanises the impacts. We need a multi-pronged approach, involving border checks, testing, contact tracing, isolation support and increased health funding. John also ignored the fact that herd immunity is best done via the safety of vaccination! Which will come along in a year or so. After which, we won't have to "get rid of every case in the world".

snippet.textDisplay: Two points make this "herd immunity" unlogic und unrealistic: First, you can never be sure that the death rate will be around 1% without medical care. All the data (death rate) that we have now is based on all countries' proactive medical reaction to the patients. But we really have little knowledge about this virus. If people with mild symtoms stay at home and overall the number of people infected reaches the so-called peak, how can you be sure that these people will recover by themselves without medical intervention? How can you be sure that people will be immune by sacrificing a speculated small number of people, which is utterly inhuman. Even if these people infected would get medical intervention to be immune, how can you be sure that the medical system can withstand? Second, where does this conclusion "The virus will come back" come from? One realistic way to help people immune is to develop vaccine, which China is wasting no time doing so. Just think how hundreds of thousands of potential viruses in the nature. If we think that the virus will come back, so we have to be naturally "immune" to it, then the only way that we can prevent all the viruses combing back is to sacrifice some people, be immune to one type of virus, repeat this pattern, and all die.

snippet.textDisplay: I think Nick Phin is right. This virus is highly contagious and spreading exponentially. There's only two things that can stop it; a vaccine, or reaching the herd immunity point. Ideally we'd self isolate all the most vulnerable people, while the healthy ones go out and voluntarily get the virus, recover and become immune, thereby reaching the herd immunity point. But if that's not possible, then we need to approximate that scenario as close as we can. If we shut the country down too quick, the virus will just spread again when we open it back up again. Italy and China will learn this soon.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’ve been listening to a lot of fake news or misunderstandings about the situation in Italy: journalists and politicians in the US and the UK continue to refer to the cautelative measures taken as a lockdown not different from what went down in China. 
Except Italy is still a democratic and free country, we've been asked and given collaboration in a steady dialogue and a communal effort with our government: we are not prisoners, we can go out to work and for sensible reasons. The police is able to control whoever is traveling around and you can be given a ticket or been pursued if you are joking around and putting others in danger. 
Again we’ve been asked to collaborate freely, and more important people at home won’t loose their job because of our country welfare system. 
Schools may be closed but teachers and kids are all continuing to do their jobs learning through the websites schools are providing and social media. 
It is well known that our healthcare is free and accessible for everyone, non-italian citizens included. Our doctors, nurses and medical personnel are working non stop for weeks now, and in the north of Italy our hospitals, ICU, techs and supplies were likely much more efficient and numerous than in other advanced and rich countries, due to the larger number of senior citizens our country has. That's the reason behind the great concern we are showing. We care for our elders. We are fighting hard, we aren't caricature of people singing through a window without a worry. People are singing and playing instruments by the windows to tell others that they are not alone. We are free. We stay at home. We care.
